Award.AwardTitle: Portable Kit for Experiential Learning in Programmable Logic Controller Education (PortablePLC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is (1) designing and building a low-cost portable Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) kit with quick-disconnect modules for teaching about basic I/O devices, sensors, and automated systems; (2) creating instructional support materials that apply experiential learning strategies to integrate the PLC kit with lectures, out of class assignments, and lab exercises; (3) developing faculty expertise in integrating the PLC kit into course curricula; (4) evaluating the developed PLC kit and instructional support materials; and (5) disseminating the materials and findings through workshops, web pages, and the institutionalization of the developed materials. The developed kits and experiential learning materials are being evaluated in at least four undergraduate courses at Texas A&M University and in six courses at three universities with a high enrollment of underrepresented minorities, potentially impacting at least 280 students at TAMU and at least 120 students at the other institutions. In addition, the dissemination plan provides for further outreach to two-year colleges, minority serving institutions, and industry. This ensures that students from all backgrounds have an opportunity to learn PLC programming concepts.

The project evaluation activities expand the body of knowledge about applications of experiential learning to engineering education. The results of this research advance knowledge in the area of automated manufacturing system integration, benefit the manufacturing industry, system integrators, and consumers and increase US competitiveness in manufacturing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Automation has a profound effect on the way we do work.  Across the five major industry groups that employ more than 40 percent of all manufacturing employees, nearly three out of every four plants use advanced manufacturing technology. According to U.S. Census Bureau reports, in 2015, the U.S. exported $16.04 billion in advanced technology products in the flexible manufacturing category—up 3.3% from $15.5 billion in 2014 and $14.5 billion in 2013.  This trend is likely to continue to increase as the manufacturing sector continues to transform to a high tech, less labor-intensive and value added industry using advanced automated systems.  However, skilled engineers who can operate, maintain, design and build such systems are increasingly difficult to find, even though industrial automation jobs tend to pay better than other professions.

At the heart of every manufacturing system is a programmable logic controller (PLC). PLCs make process automation possible by orchestrating and synchronizing processes to ensure that every activity happens in a controlled and coordinated manner.  Students who are pursuing careers in industrial automation and control industry need to learn about programming PLCs and using them to integrate and control the components of automated systems.  However programming a PLC is quite different from programming a computer; it requires learning ladder logic, a specialized language for industry automation and control that requires understanding how to interface (wire) devices and equipment. Because of limitations in equipment availability, it is often difficult for students to gain the experience needed to become proficient with PLCs. The exposure that they get is typically limited to lab sessions during which a group of students share a single set of equipment. Often concepts are introduced during lectures, while labs are scheduled several hours or days later, which can lead to decay of knowledge. 

The Portable PLC project designed and built a low-cost portable PLC kit with quick-disconnect modules for teaching about basic I/O devices, sensors, and automated systems and created instructional support materials to integrate the PLC kit with lectures, out of class assignments, and lab exercises.  A PLC kit consists of a controller module, a plug and play I/O interface, and a special function module. There are three types of special function modules: (1) basic I/O module, (2) sensor module, and (3) automated system module.

Evaluations of PortablePLC in the classroom suggested that the kits were well-received by students.  A common theme was that they felt that use of the kits helped them to better grasp wiring and programming of an automated system after the subjects were covered in the class. Several stated that the project helped them to visualize course materials and to integrate the lectures with real-life learning experience.  Engineers who have a deeper understanding of system integration will be better prepared to adapt to external events such as changes in production goals and processes, and organizational restructuring. This will help them to function more effectively and thereby help their companies to be more competitive in the global marketplace.
